<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 832, 93]]<|/det|>
1 When light is incident on the front of a photocell, an e.m.f. is generated in the photocell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 874, 122]]<|/det|>
A student wishes to investigate the effect of adding various thicknesses of glass in front of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 874, 138]]<|/det|>
a photocell. This may be carried out in the laboratory by varying the number of identical thin

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 660, 153]]<|/det|>
glass sheets between a light source and the front of the photocell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 849, 184]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the e.m.f. \(V\) is related to the number \(n\) of glass sheets by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 195, 532, 218]]<|/det|>
\[
V=V_{0} e^{-\alpha n t}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 228, 874, 247]]<|/det|>
where \(t\) is the thickness of one sheet, \(\alpha\) is the absorption coefficient of glass and \(V_{0}\) is the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 245, 245, 260]]<|/det|>
e.m.f. for \(n=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 874, 292]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to determine the absorption coefficient of glass. You should

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 290, 874, 307]]<|/det|>
draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 427, 323]]<|/det|>
you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>question_part<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 200, 200, 200]]<|/det|>
(a)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 337, 399, 354]]<|/det|>
(a) the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>question_part<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 200, 200, 200]]<|/det|>
(b)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 367, 416, 385]]<|/det|>
(b) the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>question_part<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 200, 200, 200]]<|/det|>
(c)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 398, 352, 417]]<|/det|>
(c) the control of variables,

<|ref|>question_part<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 200, 200, 200]]<|/det|>
(d)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 358, 448]]<|/det|>
(d) the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 443, 478]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 874, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A student is investigating how a volume of nitrogen gas is affected by the pressure exerted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 92, 163, 106]]<|/det|>
on it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 874, 138]]<|/det|>
A sample of nitrogen gas is trapped in a vertical tube of uniform cross-sectional area by a

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 874, 153]]<|/det|>
small volume of oil. Pressure is applied by a pump. The applied pressure is measured on a

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 352, 169]]<|/det|>
gauge, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[167, 179, 788, 447]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 497, 472, 512]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 528, 874, 544]]<|/det|>
An experiment is carried out to investigate how the height \(h\) of nitrogen trapped in the tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 544, 338, 559]]<|/det|>
varies with the pressure \(p\).
